//To deal with the British nationals who are not allegiant to the Queen and persecuting Hong Kongers who support democracy and freedom, a Hong Kong bill with the followings should be drafted and submitted:
1. British nationals who are assisting China to persecute Hong Kongers who support democracy and freedom will have their British nationality deprived if they are dual nationals;
2. There will be an entry ban on persons who are assisting China to persecute Hong Kongers who support democracy and freedom and their families (except British Citizens);
3. Persons who are assisting China to persecute Hong Kongers who support democracy and freedom and their families will have their assets in Britain to be frozen;
4. Criminal records on Umbrella Revolution and 2016 Mong Kok Civil Unrest (Fishball Revolution) will not affect the UK visa issuance;
5. Allowing the persons mentioned on the above to register as British Citizens / British Subjects with Right of Abode in Britain; and
6. The Parliament authorises the Prime Minister, once the Joint Declaration is seriously breached, to use all matters to revert the status of Hong Kong back to 30 June 1997//

è€Œä¸”BOCä¹‹å‰å·²ç¶“åšéä¸€æ¬¡ - when was that?

The Immigration Act 1971 was not the first legislation to limit CUKC holders from coming to the UK. The Commonwealth Immigrants Act 1962 was the first attempt to reduce the flow of CUKC from Commonwealth countries from coming to the UK. In the 1962 Act, a CUKC who was not born in the UK or have a CUKC passport issued in the UK were now subject to UK immigration control.

get something for nothing, ç‡ä½ å’©è§’åº¦å»ç‡å•¦ã€‚å¦‚æœä¿‚IA 1971å‰å‡ºç”Ÿï¼ŒåŠå…¶ä¸€ä»£å˜…å¾Œä»£å˜…BNO, å’å°±è¬›å””é€šå•¦ - I respectfully disagree. When the Brits left a colony, the usual practice was to remove British nationality from those CUKCs in that colony. In the case of Uganda in 1962, the British Parliament passed an Uganda Independence Act which stated -

Subject to the following provisions of this section, any person who immediately before the appointed date is a citizen of the United Kingdom and Colonies shall on that day cease to be such a citizen if -

a) Under the law of Uganda he becomes on that day a citizen of Uganda; and

b) he, his father his father's father was born in Uganda.

(Section 2(2) of the Uganda Independence Act 1962)

The Chinese will say that Chinese Nationality is being dealt with in the domestic legislation setting. It will be difficult for the Brits to overcome this one. The Ching Cheong (ç¨‹ç¿”) case already illustrated on the limits on what can the British government do in these cases.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_National_(Overseas)

Moreover, China does not recognize dual nationality for its nationals, and Chinese authorities considered these dual nationals solely as Chinese nationals. Chinese nationality also cannot be terminated for Chinese-descent residents holding BN(O) or British Citizenship acquired through the BNSS.[c]

As a result, BN(O)s are not entitled to British consular protection in Mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau. During a high-profile case in April 2005, Ching Cheong, a senior journalist of The Straits Times of Singapore with dual British National (Overseas) status and Chinese nationality, was detained by Chinese government for alleged espionage activities by providing state secrets to Taiwan. Until Ching's release in February 2008, the British government refused to provide consular protection, despite petitions by civil rights groups to the Foreign and Commonwealth Office (FCO). The FCO explained that they could provide assistance to Ching, but they simply could not intervene in the judicial proceedings of other countries.

Well, I can understand your view, but the fact is that you have a second nationality (Chinese) and therefore not entitle to register as a British Citizen under section 4B of the British Nationality Act 1981.

With all the talks of unfairness set aside, as I said in an earlier post, you still have the option of joining the British Army and served for at lease five years before getting British Citizenship open to you as long as you are under the age of 33.

The above option is not available to HKSAR passport holders.

By saying how unfair the system is will get you no where in the short term. All I am saying is that you are the only person that can change your own life.

Well, I can understand your view, but the fact is that you have a second nationality (Chinese) and therefore not entitle to register as a British Citizen under section 4B of the British Nationality Act 1981.

With all the talks of unfairness set aside, as I said in an earlier post, you still have the option of joining the British Army and served for at lease five years before getting British Citizenship open to you as long as you are under the age of 33.

The above option is not available to HKSAR passport holders.

By saying how unfair the system is will get you no where in the short term. All I am saying is that you are the only person that can change your own life.

forced , not by choice, OK?


Well, I can understand your view, but the fact is that you have a second nationality (Chinese) and therefore not entitle to register as a British Citizen under section 4B of the British Nationality Act 1981.

With all the talks of unfairness set aside, as I said in an earlier post, you still have the option of joining the British Army and served for at lease five years before getting British Citizenship open to you as long as you are under the age of 33.

The above option is not available to HKSAR passport holders.

By saying how unfair the system is will get you no where in the short term. All I am saying is that you are the only person that can change your own life.

ä½ æƒ³æ‹‰å»é‚Šï¼Ÿ - I am not! All I am saying is that these three pieces of legisations (Immigration Act 1971, British Nationality Act 1981 and Hong Kong Act 1985) are mainly responsible for turning someone who was born in Hong Kong from a CUKC with the right of abode in the UK to a BN(O) without the right of abode in the UK. If you think these three Acts of Parliament have been incorrectly apply, then you can always try and get a judicial review in the London courts.

'something for nothing' - you need to get over the fact that the British government has remove a lot of non UK related CUKC's right of abode in the UK from the 1960s. The majority of BN(O) passport holders do not have the right of abode in the UK. If you, as a BN(O) passport holder, wants the right of abode in the UK just now, you will need to follow the rules (just like anyone else) set out in the UK's immigration rules (residence for example) in order to get it.

All I am saying is that these three pieces of legisations (Immigration Act 1971, British Nationality Act 1981 and Hong Kong Act 1985) are mainly responsible for turning someone who was born in Hong Kong from a CUKC with the right of abode in the UK to a BN(O) without the right of abode in the UK. If you think these three Acts of Parliament have been incorrectly apply, then you can always try and get a judicial review in the London courts.

'something for nothing' - you need to get over the fact that the British government has remove a lot of non UK related CUKC's right of abode in the UK from the 1960s. The majority of BN(O) passport holders do not have the right of abode in the UK. If you, as a BN(O) passport holder, wants the right of abode in the UK just now, you will need to follow the rules (just like anyone else) set out in the UK's immigration rules (residence for example) in order to get it.
